title: Don Letts webchat â your questions answered on reggae, the Clash and Gabicci cardigans | Culture | The Guardian
summary: people turning problems into assets , using what they had , it was very diy . as was the birth of hip-hop .
i never went to the rock against racism concert . joe strummer had run away with my girlfriend that day .
i think we set things back a generation , cos it 's my grandkids reacting against my straight kids that will be the next rebels .
the don do n't play games . i 've never even been to a football match .
i got to write some great songs with mick jones . and i 'd do it again tomorrow - come on , mick !
don letts webchat post your questions now .

text: guardian contributor donletts 01 august 2017 3:55pm this is don letts , over and out .
superspid asks : hey don , recently seen lots of your dj sets popping up around the country , is this something you 're doing more of ?
would love to see you down here near truro !
guardian contributor donletts 01 august 2017 3:43pm i 've been djing nationally and internationally for the last 20 years .
it 's my way of having a cultural conversations and keeping a contemporary ear to the ground .
i do love to nice up the place with some heavyweight bass as my sets are very much in the spirit of my days as dj at the legendary roxy club .
catch me if you can .
wheelie07030 asks : there 's a growing trend ( from the left ) to rail against artists deemed guilty of cultural appropriation , ie privileged white performers ripping off black culture and artists .
what are your thoughts on that ?
to show my hand , as a white bloke who got into reggae and other cultures because of the clash , i think it 's bizarre .
guardian contributor donletts 01 august 2017 3:52pm this cultural appropriation thing does n't really stand up to any serious analysis .
it seems to me that a certain amount of creativity and inspiration comes from a culture exchange .
but there 's a big difference between inspiration and imitation .
orso asks : do you think that the punk-reggae crossover has ever been properly recognised for the influence it had ?
without it i would never have started listening to black music but , as a result , have been taken down a path that includes free jazz , lovers rock , funk , and the chi-lites for example .
guardian contributor donletts 01 august 2017 3:51pm well it has been recognised by me - see my film two sevens clash , because that 's what it 's all about .
a more approach to creativity and not necessarily just those two genres per se .

documents.title: i never went to the rock against racism concert . joe strummer had run away with my girlfriend that day
text: wryneck201 asks : the rock against racism concert in victoria park in 78 was , in my opinion , the best the clash ever played .
do you agree ?
guardian contributor donletts 01 august 2017 3:49pm you know i never went to the rock against racism concert .
i put my political concerns on the back burner that day because joe strummer had run away with my girlfriend and i was at home blubbering instead .

diedug asks : now things have calmed down the roxy has shut , the clash and the pistols have gone , malcolm 's dead and we can look back and see how everything 's turned to shit , do you feel it was worth it ?
guardian contributor donletts 01 august 2017 3:48pm i would n't be who i am today if it was n't for punk rock .
and as i said before , it can work for you too .
bookseeker asks : is there anything about you today that is in any way a residue of the young skinhead ?
guardian contributor donletts 01 august 2017 3:48pm attention to detail and style .
jonah drumm asks : prince or bowie ?
guardian contributor donletts 01 august 2017 3:47pm what 's with this either/or thing ?
it 's a very 21st century thing that you 're either into this or that .
the great thing is that both exist .
and you can have it all .

documents.title: the don do n't play games . i 've never even been to a football match
text: vammyp asks : when you play mario kart , which character do you choose ?
guardian contributor donletts 01 august 2017 3:46pm the don do n't play games .
seriously , i 've never even been to a football match .
billy2times asks : do you think music today is a busted flush ?
i mean is there anything out there that 's ever going to stand alongside the beatles , the stones , dylan , marley or smokey robinson ?
guardian contributor donletts 01 august 2017 3:45pm i 'm a great believer that every generation needs its own soundtrack .
so the answer to that question for you , is no .
the answer to that question for someone that might not have heard of any of those bands , is yes .
stockwellcarrot asks : i saw your documentary on skinheads .
in your opinion , which youth culture has had the greatest cultural effect ?
in my lifetime , i think the way acid house bought people together was a huge cultural shift .
guardian contributor donletts 01 august 2017 3:44pm the youth culture that will have the greatest effect is the one that you were involved with .
1to618 asks : will dub ever die ?
guardian contributor donletts 01 august 2017 3:42pm dub has become part of the fabric of popular music .
a lot of contemporary sounds owe a great debt to jamaica and its gift to the world - bass .

haigin88 asks : i vaguely remember reading some story about you having little coloured stickers placed onto the keys of your keyboard in big audio dynamite to help you play the required parts but then , during the performance , the colours on the stickers all changed and you were left flailing around .
seems a little spinal tap but was that you , someone else or did i imagine it ?
guardian contributor donletts 01 august 2017 3:41pm it 's true , when i performed with big audio dynamite i did have coloured stickers on my keyboard as i could n't play a musical instrument .
still ca n't .
but that was my strength .
mick got me involved because my ideas came from other places .
where do you think all the samples and dialogue came from ?
you know , paul simonon actually learned to play by placing stickers on the fret of his bass .
the difference between me and paul is , he eventually removed the stickers .
ps the coloured lights story is true , as is spinal tap
dwfan1 asks : what 's your favourite pixar film ?
guardian contributor donletts 01 august 2017 3:38pm clever as they are , at the end of the day i have to say i 'm a studio ghibli fan .

documents.title: people turning problems into assets , using what they had , it was very diy . as was the birth of hip-hop
text: alexito asks : i reckon punk gets a bit too much credit for inventing a diy indie approach that uk reggae musicians ( as well as plenty of others ) had already been developing for years in the uk .
do you agree ?
guardian contributor donletts 01 august 2017 3:38pm the punk spirit and attitude obviously did not begin and end in the late 70s .
it has a lineage and tradition that predates that period and goes way beyond music .
having said that , it was the explosion of the '77 punk movement that made me realise that the invention of reggae was a punk rock moment too .
it was people turning problems into assets , using what they had to get what they needed , and it was very diy .
as was the birth of hip-hop .
this realisation is very important because punk rock is not a dead thing .
it 's not something to look back on , it 's something to look forward to if you 've got a good idea and you 're brave enough .
and it was the '77 incarnation of this spirit that made me who i am today .
worked for me , it can work for you too .
loumo asks : i feel woefully ignorant about reggae and would like to listen to more , but the choice is so vast that i do n't know where to start .
i like what i 've heard of john holt , steel pulse and congos , and i enjoy the dub that i 've heard .
is there a cd or lp ( not downloads please , i 'm old ) that you 'd recommend for a beginner ?
guardian contributor donletts 01 august 2017 3:34pm refer to the question below , and i suggest my podcasts are worth getting over your fear of technology for .
it 's only a couple of clicks for christ 's sake .
loveinkforlife asks : could you please recommend some good reggae musicians who are in the music scene now , as i am struggling to find one that can play good traditional sound with decent lyrics .
guardian contributor donletts 01 august 2017 3:33pm without sounding like a dick , i do have to flag up my recent podcasts for turtle bay , which look at my lifelong passion for reggae .
and consequently feature hand tunes that have captured my imagination over the years .
also , to sound like a dick , i 've put together around four or five reggae compilations that come highly recommended .
whitewall66 asks : how many gabicci cardigans do you have ?
guardian contributor donletts 01 august 2017 3:31pm five .
notinamillion asks : two questions , with apologies for any impertinence .
in terms of practising what they preached , the missus reckons lennon , i reckon strummer .
what do you think ?
secondly , do you think grime is the closest to punk since 76 .
guardian contributor donletts 01 august 2017 3:30pm both .
lennon was relevant for his generation , and strummer was relevant for mine .
in both cases warts and all .
you know , it 's important that we keep these people real , because then it becomes something we can aspire to .
it 's important that we do n't put them on pedestals and make them unreal .
re grime : i think a lot of the new expressions in music owe a debt to punk .
and all consequent events after the late 70s seem to have benefited from elements of the punk spirit and attitude - well the ones i like .

documents.title: i think we set things back a generation , cos it 's my grandkids reacting against my straight kids that will be the next rebels
text: johnbehets asks : having been brought up in a generation where everything was constantly changing music- and fashion-wise ( i 'm 54 ) , do you agree that things are a bit staid right now ?
if so , where do you think the next big thingwill come from ?
if you do n't agree , enlighten me as to where the new unique sounds and sights are .
guardian contributor donletts 01 august 2017 3:28pm interesting question .
because i do find myself wondering how the hell did the grown ups become cooler than the kids ?
then i realise that maybe it 's our fault .
i mean , how do you rebel against your parents if they were a punk rocker or a raver or whatever ?
you go straight , right ?
and maybe it 's our fault that many of the young people today are so conservative .
i mean we 've not left a lot of stones unturned for them to express themselves .
and the fact that my generation have had an extended youth , has n't really helped .
i 've come to the conclusion that actually we 've set things back a generation , 'cos it 's my grandkids reacting against my straight kids , that will be the next rebels .
reamonn23 asks : did you ever meet mikey dread whom i think should be more recognised and widely known as a great artist .
i remember being at an orb gig in dublin just after his death and patterson sneaked in a sample of dread at the controls into towers of dub ( i think ) in his honour , which i will always remember .
guardian contributor donletts 01 august 2017 3:25pm i actually gave paul simonon some cassette tapes of mikey 's dread at the controls radio show from kingston , jamaica .
and it was these tapes that prompted paul to track mikey down to work with on sandinista .
mikey became a good friend of us all and with regards to how recognised he is , i think those that are supposed to know , know .
alastair burnett asks : what 's the best bit of music movie footage that you have tucked away that 's never seen the light of day ?
guardian contributor donletts 01 august 2017 3:24pm nothing .
i 've got nothing tucked away .
it 's about passing it on , man , nothing is supposed to be secret .
my latest film `` two sevens clash '' which looks at the myth and the reality of the punky reggae party does include a lot of unseen material however .
1234ramones asks : what 's better , complete control or white man in hammersmith palais ?
and is it correct you took strummer to said venue on the night that influenced said song ?
i 've read your autobiography but my mind 's like a sieve i 'm sure you mentioned it .

guardian contributor donletts 01 august 2017 3:22pm they both have a place and a purpose - but white man will always have the edge for me as i was lucky enough to be the person to take strummer to the hammersmith palais on the night that inspired the record .
and he really was the only white man in hammersmith palais .
mikeybirdzis1234 asks : how difficult was djing with just one turntable at the roxy back in the day , and do you recall the actual tech setup ?
what are your thoughts on djing these days ?
and will the clash on broadway ever come out as a full proper film/dvd ?
guardian contributor donletts 01 august 2017 3:21pm i got the gig djing at the roxy by accident .
and fortunately or unfortunately only one deck worked .
that was great for me as i 'd never dj 'd in my life .
luckily , in soundsystem tradition there was only one deck anyway .
and the gaps between the records were crucial because you could gauge the vibe of the room and the people .
in fact those gaps in between tracks were also instrumental in the creation of rap , but that 's another story .
lordhawking asks : when i think of reggae 's golden age in the 70s , a lot of artists were big on the theme of repatriation to africa .
i 've often wondered whether this call was meant literally or not .
did any artists actually return and , if not , any thoughts as to why ?

guardian contributor donletts 01 august 2017 3:19pm the back to africa school of thought - changed to forward to africa by rastafari by the way - was really about overcoming eurocentric values and aspirations .
it was about looking to the history and culture of africa to enlighten and liberate the people , and realise that our history did not begin with slavery .
kdcm2017 asks : it 's obvious that music has a huge influence on fashion and trends , but what influences do you think it has on things like food ?
can music make food taste better and can food make music an even better experience ?
guardian contributor donletts 01 august 2017 3:16pm funny you should ask as i 've just put together a series of podcasts , somewhat prompted by the association of music and food .
i guess they 're both forms of nourishment .
and if you go to notting hill carnival , i 'm sure you 'll find a lot of people who will agree .
noirnoirnoir asks : what time do you wake up ?
guardian contributor donletts 01 august 2017 3:13pm listen , i 've got a tribe of kids .
and somehow i 've always had to get up with them .
so basically i get up at 8am on average , even if i go to bed at 4am .
i 've heard it said that the morning is a very creative part of the day .
the don concurs .
having said that , you do realise that the morning starts after midnight - so it could equally be said that late night sessions are just as relevant .
itsascreamer asks : what is your take on british youth culture today , as opposed to the situation in 1977 down the roxy ?
is it getting better for the youth , has it got worse , or have you seen no change over the last 40 years ?
guardian contributor donletts 01 august 2017 3:11pm you know , a lot of what we did in the late 70s happened because of how little we had , not how much we had .
the old adage that necessity is the mother of invention comes to mind .
here we are in the 21st century when the digital age and affordable technology has given the youth the means to express themselves .
but it seems to me , andy warhol 's vision of everyone being famous for 15 minutes has turned into a nightmare of people that ca n't justify three .
just because you can afford it , do n't mean you can do it .
and the downside of affordable technology is mediocrity .
having said that , technology ai n't the problem .
it 's the people , man , and how we use it .
look at facebook for example - in the west , a complete waste of time , people 's ugly kids and what they 've just had for lunch .
in other parts of the world , it 's a life saving device .
bottom line is - technology is great , people are shit .
itsascreamer asks : hey don !
big up for playing dub down the roxy where it all began for punk in the uk .
do you follow jungle and what is your take on it ?
respect .
guardian contributor donletts 01 august 2017 3:12pm the don does n't follow anything .
my take on jungle , well it 's a child of reggae , and i 'm open to anything with a wicked bassline .

documents.title: i got to write some great songs with mick jones . and i 'd do it again tomorrow - come on , mick !
text: spiritditch asks : following the relatively recent bad tour , do you regard the band as unfinished business ?
new material or a further tour would be awesome .
genuinely do n't think i have witnessed a better comeback tour .
the shows i attended blew me away , big style !
guardian contributor donletts 01 august 2017 3:08pm i do n't know about unfinished business but i 'm really proud of the fact that i got to write some great songs with mick jones .
and i 'd do it again tomorrow if he was up for it - come on mick !
spiritditch asks : as an artist who has been a successful film-maker , band member and dj , which of the genres are you most proud of ?
guardian contributor donletts 01 august 2017 3:07pm i 've always seen each element of what i do as part of a whole .
very much in the spirit of how we operate as human beings .
our five senses complement each other .
and with a good soundtrack it 's even better .
bernie sanders 1888 asks : do you believe # grime4corbyn is a sustainable movement to enthuse the younger generation behind a progressive political agenda ?
guardian contributor donletts 01 august 2017 3:03pm does n't matter if it 's sustainable , i 'm just glad that young people have got off their arses and got involved .
period .
it 's been a long time coming .
i guess prompted by the fact that they realise policies they did n't vote for ( not voting - big problem , period ) are affecting them directly .
brexit being a prime example .
i 've had my life so it ai n't gon na bother me , it 's the young ones i feel for .

johnellam asks : with organisers of live events having to submit form 696 to please the met police , would your dad have have been able to organise his superstonic sound events in london if he were doing so today ?
guardian contributor donletts 01 august 2017 3:01pm shit , i did n't know white people had to fill that in too - i thought it was a straight up racist request .
having said that , the soundsystem my father operated would have been very different to the ones you know today .
held in the local church hall , as opposed to a basement with one lightbulb , my father 's generation would have been more likely to have been carrying a bible as opposed to a bag of weed .
having said all that these gatherings provided a serious social function for strangers in a strange land .
oysterbloke asks : u-roy 's do n't touch i man locks still sends shivers down the back of my neck every time i hear it .
what still track does it for you ?
thanks for bbc 6music culture clash show .
guardian contributor donletts 01 august 2017 2:59pm i 'm as old as rock'n'roll so to ask me to just one song is quite a task .

off the top of my head - haha - i 'd say marvin gaye 's what 's going on comes to mind , augustus pablo `` king tubby meets rockers uptown '' , beach boys `` do n't cry , put your head on my shoulder '' and the pistols ' anarchy in the uk .
stevehiggs asks : no 10 upping st is one of the best albums released in the 80 's , did you realise you 'd made a classic when you finished it ?
guardian contributor donletts 01 august 2017 2:56pm the making of the album ended up very differently to how it started .

when joe strummer came to the studio one day and never left , it was an honour to see he and mick creatively fall in love again - although i always hated the title of the album which was a pun on 10 downing street .
joe thought it was very funny and i 'm sure most people never got .
all in all i 'm very proud of everything big audio dynamite did .
don letts is with us now don letts in the guardian office jonze

documents.title: don letts webchat post your questions now
text: nobody could dispute don letts ' punk credentials .
he 's made videos for public image ltd and the clash , managed the slits , dj 'd at london 's roxy club and played in big audio dynamite with mick jones .

it was letts who put together the punk rock movie in 1978 from his own super 8 footage of the burgeoning scene , and letts who returned to the story in 2000 for the grammy-winning the clash : westway to the world .
but that 's just one side of his character .
the londoner has been involved in fashion and films , and currently djs across the world .

he also hosts don letts ' culture clash radio on bbc 6 music , and has partnered with the restaurant chain turtle bay for the 45 podcast , which aims to deliver reggae 's underground sounds to diners .
above all , letts is a great storyteller , which means you should jump at the chance to grill him on everything from visiting jamaica with john lydon to his friendship with bob marley .
letts will be joining us in the office for a live webchat at 3pm uk time on tuesday 1 august .
please post your questions for him in the comment section below .

bulletin.text: The film-maker, DJ and musician talks about the birth of punk, the power of reggae and the day Joe Strummer ran off with his girlfriend.
